sen.e: Incidentally, the word "Kanto" in this case indicates the Kamakura shogunate itself rather than the location of the provinces, (today, "Kanto" specify the central-eastern region of Japan including Tokyo, and Kamakura, where shogunate was also established) therefore Kanto Gobunkoku meant not just the provinces located in the eastern region, but also the provinces located in the western part of Japan under the ruling of Kamakura shogunate.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の関東御分国
sen.e: Kanto Gobunkoku during Kamakura period
Kanto Gobunkoku during the Kamakura period

sen.j: 鎌倉時代の関東御分国は、将軍家が知行国主として支配し、一族や御家人を朝廷に推挙して国司に任じ、国衙領（公領）を支配するとともに、国衙領からの収入を得た。
sen.e: The form of Kanto Gobunkoku in Kamakura period was that the family/clan members or the retainers of Kamakura shogunate were recommended to the Imperial Court for the nomination of the provincial officials, in order to rule the provinces as the officials of Kokugaryo (Imperial province) and properly earn the revenue from the province.

sen.e: The form of Kanto Gobunkoku in the Kamakura period was that the family/clan members or the retainers of the Kamakura shogunate were recommended to the Imperial Court for nomination as provincial officials, in order to rule the provinces as the officials of Kokugaryo (Imperial province) and properly earn revenue from the province.

The form of Kanto Gobunkoku in the Kamakura period was that the family/clan members or the retainers of the Kamakura bakufu were recommended to the Imperial Court for nomination as provincial officials, in order to rule the provinces as the officials of Kokugaryo (Imperial province) and properly earn revenue from the province.

sen.j: 文治元年（1185年）には9ヵ国に達したが、源実朝の時代には4ヵ国に減少する。
sen.e: In 1185, the number of Kanto Gobunkoku reached the highest to 9, although the number of Kanto Gobunkoku decreased to 4 during the reign of MINAMOTO no Sanetomo, the third and the last shogun of Kamakura shogunate.

sen.e: While Kanto Gobunkoku played a a great role for securing the ruling of Kamakura shogunate during its incipient time, its importance was reduced once the shogunate order was established and stabilized, and the number of the province gradually decreased.

sen.e: The Kanto Gobunkoku remained until the fall of Kamakura shogunate were Suruga Province, Sagami Province, Musashi Province, Echigo Province, while the officials assigned to Sagami Province and Musashi Province were regent/cosignatory of Kamakura shogunate.
